Graphical abstract This paper describes the synthesis, characterisation and catalytic transfer hydrogenation reaction of nitro compounds using HCOOH as hydrogen donor and functionalized chloromethylated polystyrene divinylbenzene supported iron complex as catalyst. It was characterized by various analytical techniques such as elemental analysis, ICP-OES, UV–VIS-DRS and FT-IR spectroscopic techniques, EDAX, and thermogravimetric analysis. This supported complex is an efficient catalyst for transfer hydrogenation reaction of aliphatic and aromatic nitro compounds which find application in the synthesis of fine chemicals, API’s and drugs. Interestingly this method has been proven to be tolerant to a broad range of functional groups with good to excellent yields and also established to be superior by exhibiting better catalytic activity and recyclability than the unsupported catalyst. The supported catalyst could be reused seven times without significant loss of catalytic activity. Density functional theory studies shreds light on the possible reaction pathways of transfer hydrogenation reaction catalyzed by Fe(III) system. Keywords Heterogeneous catalyst Transfer hydrogenation Nitro compounds Substituted benzimidazole Amines Hydrogen donor Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Polymer supported catalysts are polymers possessing catalytically active moieties. The polymer supported catalysts are used in organic and pharmaceutical chemistry as well as chemical engineering [1]. Their applications have been found in organic synthesis, biological applications, battery chemistry [2] etc. Reaction work-up is simpler as the supported catalysts are easily separated from the reaction mixture by filtration. Since it shows good tenacity, recyclability and low-bleeding system, the focus in this area of research will lie in the development of catalysts for asymmetric reactions as well as for large-scale reactions. It can be recycled and reused [3]; thus, it is very important economically and makes it industrially attractant. They are non-toxic, non-volatile, odourless and environmentally more acceptable. Continuously, the quest for novel, gentle, and specific techniques for altering functional groups remains a pivotal motivation in the field of synthetic organic chemistry. Aromatic amines, commonly employed as pivotal intermediates in the synthesis of vital compounds like dyes, pharmaceuticals, and agricultural chemicals, can be readily synthesized by initially introducing a nitro group, followed by either catalytic molecular hydrogenation [4] or catalytic transfer hydrogenation [5], employing diverse sets of conditions. Molecular hydrogen is a gas of low molecular weight and highly diffusible, has low ignition temperature particularly can cause considerable hazard on the large-scale production. In catalytic transfer hydrogenation, the reaction condition is mild, procedure employs simple reaction set-up. Achieving the selective transfer hydrogenation of the nitro group stands as a critical milestone in synthesizing pharmaceuticals like vardenafil [6], the antibiotic tedizolid [7], and the HIV protease inhibitor darunavir (Prezista) [8]. Various techniques have emerged to facilitate this transformation, encompassing approaches such as sodium borohydride and hydrazine as hydrogen donors in the presence of catalyst [9,10], various metals like tin or zinc [11], and an array of catalytic systems including N-substituted DBU [12], Au /Rutile [13], Pd /g-C3N4 [14], CO [15], Pd nanoparticles immobilized on silica [16], Pd on glasswool [17], heterogeneous non-noble-metal catalyst consisting of cobalt-nitrogen complex supported on nitrogen doped carbon [18], and CeY zeolite with HCOOH or HCOONH4 [19]. The use of cheaper abundant transition metals like iron is advantageous in catalysis research [20,21], especially in areas like organic synthesis [22,23]and industrial processes [24]. Iron can sometimes mimic the catalytic activity of precious metals while being much cheaper and more sustainable [25]. Its versatility allows to participate in a wide range of catalytic transformations like cross-coupling [26], oxidation and redox reactions, Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and even photocatalysis [27]. Beller et al conducted the conversion of nitro compounds using FeBr2/P(cy)3 as catalyst alongside PhSiH3 as a hydrogen source in toluene showed good regioselective and chemo selective. Despite achieving high selectivity and conversion, use of poisonous tricyclohexylphosphine and toluene as solvent and the extended reaction duration; restricted the applicability of the reaction for large scale production [28]. Nevertheless, many synthetic methodologies still lack the desired chemoselectivity concerning other functional groups commonly present in the substrates. Iron complexes have been successfully applied in different forms for selective nitro to amine transformation [29]. As there is a continual demand for an enhanced, environmentally friendly, and chemoselective method for hydrogen transfer reaction, herein the selective conversion of aromatic nitro compounds to amines catalyzed by polymer-supported iron complex, employing acetic acid as hydrogen source in water-ethyl acetate medium has been attempted. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals and reagents Chloromethylated polystyrene divinyl benzene copolymer with 6.5 % crosslinking (PS) were from Thermax Ltd, Pune, India. The other chemicals like FeCl3, 2-mercapto benzimidazole, chloroacetic acid and nitro compounds were of Merck-Sigma Aldrich (A R Grade) and were used without further purification. All the solvents were distilled prior to use by standard methods [30]. All organic chemicals used were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker (400MHz) spectrometer in CDCl3 or DMSO‑d 6 as solvent, and chemical shifts are expressed as ppm. High resolution mass spectra were taken on a Bruker Daltonics instrument and mass spectra on a Agilent LC-MS. The elemental analyses were carried out using an Elemental Vario Cube CHNS rapid Analyzer. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC pre-coated silica gel G plates. 2.2 Experimental 2.2.1 Preparation of the functionalized polymer [PS-(2-TMBB-H)] The ligand 2-(thiomethyl-2l-benzimidazolyl)-benzimidazole (2-TMBB-H2) was synthesized by reacting 2- chloromethyl benzimidazole and 2- mercapto benzimidazole [31]. Chloromethylated polystyrene cross-linked with 6.5 % divinyl benzene polymer beads (PS) were washed with a mixture of THF and H2O (4:1) using a Soxhlet extractor for 12 h and vacuum dried. PS (1 g) was soaked in DMF for about 2 h to swell. Ligand (2-TMBB-H2) (1.1 g) dissolved in 20 ml DMF, 4 ml triethylamine and 35 ml ethyl acetate was added to it and stirred for 48 h at 60˚C. Resulting light brown color beads were filtered off, washed with DMF, Soxhlet extracted with methanol to remove unreacted ligand and dried in an oven at 100˚C (Yield: 1.5 g). [Scheme 1.1 ] 2.2.2 Preparation of the polymer bound Fe(III) complex PS-Fe(OH2)(2-TMBB-H)Cl3 The functionalized polymer beads (1 g) were soaked in 10 ml DMF for 2 h and filtered. A solution of FeCl3 1.086 g, 1 mmol (in 1 drop of conc. HCl) in methanol was added to it and the mixture was heated on water bath for about 48 h. The resulting reddish-brown beads were filtered off, Soxhlet extracted with methanol and dried under vacuum. (Yield: 1.3 g). [Scheme 1.1] 2.2.3 Preparation of the unbound Fe(III) complex [Fe(OH2)(Cl)(2-TMBB-H2)2]Cl2 The unsupported complex [Fe(OH2)(Cl)(2-TMBB-H2)2]Cl2 was prepared by reacting 2-TMBB-H2 (2 mmol) [31] and FeCl3 (1 mmol in 2 drops of conc. HCl) in 20 mL methanol at 60 °C for 5 h. The resulting reddish brown coloured complex was filtered, washed and vacuum dried. (Yield: 89 %). [Scheme 1.2 ] 2.3 Characterization The elemental analyses were obtained with an Elementar Vario ELII CHNS analyzer. The iron content was determined using ICP-OES. The UV–visible-DRS spectra were measured using a Shimadzu, Model: UV3600 UV–Vis-NIR spectrophotometer having an integrating sphere attachment for the solid samples in BaSO4. The FTIR spectra of the samples were recorded in the range 400–4000 cm−1 as KBr disks on a Bruker FT-IR spectrometer. Thermograms were recorded on a TA instrument under nitrogen atmosphere with heating rate of 10 °C/min from room temperature to 600 °C. All the probe reaction products were analyzed using NMR and LCMS/HRMS. Computational studies were carried out using Gaussian 09 software package. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical properties and analytical data Elemental analyses of the functionalized polymer beads indicated 4.41 % N which revealed the successful functionalization of the polymer with 2-TMBB-H2. The iron content in the unbound and polymer supported complexes were determined by ICP-OES and was found to be 7.35 and 3.55 % respectively. The molar conductivity of [Fe(OH2)(Cl)(2-TMBB-H2)2]Cl2 complex in DMF was found to be 168 Ώ−1 cm2 mol−1 indicating 1:2 electrolytic nature of the complex. The physical properties and analytical data of polymer, functionalized polymer, unbound and polymer bound Fe(III) complexes are tabulated in the Table 1 . 3.2 FT-IR spectral & EDAX studies The FT-IR spectra of [Fe(OH2)(Cl)(2-TMBB-H2)2]Cl2 and PS-[Fe(OH2)(2-TMBB-H)Cl3] are depicted in the Fig. 1 . Also PS, 2-TMBB-H2, [PS-(2-TMBB-H)] are displayed in supplementary material SI02A. The FT-IR spectrum of chloromethylated polystyrene beads (PS) exhibited a peak at 1265 cm−1 due to ѴCH2Cl on functionalization with ligand a decrease in the peak intensity was observed in [PS-(2-TMBB-H)] indicating the bonding of 2-TMBB-H to the polymer. PS(2-TMBB-H) exhibited a peak around 3425 cm−1 assigned to Ѵ N-H and the PS-Fe(III)(2-TMBB-H) exhibited a peak around 3434 cm−1 due to Ѵ N-H and Ѵ O-H (due to co-ordinated water). The functionalized polymer displayed a peak at 1617 cm−1 due to Ѵ C=N, which was shifted to 1627 cm−1 in polymer bound complex, indicating nitrogen of benzimidazole moieties of ligand is coordinated to iron centre. The EDAX of functionalized polymer displayed peaks due to N and S in addition to carbon, supporting the binding of ligand to the polymer (Fig. 2 ). The EDAX of polymer anchored metal complex exhibited an additional peak due to Fe, signifying that the metal is bounded to the functionalized polymer. 3.3 Diffused reflectance spectral studies of PS-[Fe(OH2)(2-TMBB-H)Cl3] and [Fe(OH2)(Cl)(2-TMBB-H2)2]Cl2 Diffused reflectance spectra of ligand, polymer, functionalized polymer, anchored complex and unsupported complexes have been recorded (Fig. 3 and supplimentary material SIO2B). The ligand 2-TMBB-H2 exhibited bands in the range 210–422 nm due to π → π* and n → π* transitions. The polymer displayed bands around 206 and 274 nm. The functionalized polymer showed bands due to both ligand and polymer. Anchored complex in addition to polymer and ligand bands displayed bands due to metal complex. The bands around 210, 268, 378 nm are due to polymer and ligand. The d-d transitions exhibited by metal complex were weak and found around 503, 536 and 705 nm which were assigned to 6A1g→4A1g , 6A1g→4T2g and 6A1g→4T1g transitions of high spin d5 distorted octahedral coordination around iron. The spectrum of unsupported complex was similar to anchored complex and exhibited bands due to ligand and d-d transitions around 500,542, and 694 nm indicating distorted octahedral high spin d5 Fe(III) system [32]. 3.4 Thermal analysis The TGA curves of polymer and functionalised polymer indicated that they are stable upto 260 °C and 210 °C respectively (Fig. 4 ). The anchored polymer PS-Fe(OH2)(2-TMBB-H)Cl3 exhibited 5 % weight loss indicating the presence of coordinated water and the loss of three chlorides is observed in the range 250––450 °C. The unsupported complex showed 3 % weight loss indicating the presence of coordinated water and the loss of two chloride ions are observed in the range 200–225 °C. The third decomposition in the range 250–460 °C which could be due to the decomposition of ligand which is 37 %. 3.5 Application studies on hydrogen transfer reaction Motivated by the increased understanding of complex catalysed transfer hydrogenation reaction [33–35] the next investigations were focused on the applicability of synthesized anchored complex PS-Fe(OH2)(2-TMBB-H)(Cl)3 towards the transfer hydrogenation of nitro compounds. For this 4-nitrobenzoic acid was chosen as the reactant using formic acid as hydrogen source under different catalytic loading conditions at 70 °C for 6 h as indicated in Scheme 2 , Table 2 . Screening of PS-[Fe(OH2)(2-TMBB-H)Cl3] catalyst under various conditions suggested that, among solvents water/ethyl acetate (1:1), and water/ 2- methyl THF (1:1) proved very effective (Table 2, entries 10 to 15), The unsupported catalyst under the same condition gave very less yield (50 %) and was non −recyclable. Solvent used lead to major effecton the product yield (Table 2). Very good yields were obtained in water/ ethyl acetate, Water/ 2- methyl THF. The most robust reaction was achieved by the use of 12 mol% of PS-[Fe(OH2)(2-TMBB-H)Cl3] with 90 % yield (Table 2 entry 11). Further investigation revealed that there was no considerable improvement in yield when the catalyst loading was increased to 15 mol% (Table 2, entry 13), whereas the yield dropped to 69 % when the reaction time was reduced to 5 h with 15 mol% catalyst (Table 2 entry 15). The nature of the hydrogen donor also influences the selectivity and activity of the reaction. The choice of the donor is based on the nature of the reaction [36], its availability, low oxidation potential and solubility in the reaction medium. To study the influence of the hydrogen donor on the catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH), reactions were carried out using 1 mmole of p-nitrobenzoic acid, 12 mol % of catalyst, 3 eq. of hydrogen donor, 6 mL of solvent at 70°C. Hydrogen donors used such as hydrazine hydrate (N2H4·H2O), isopropyl alcohol (ipa), HCOOH, HCOOK and HCOONH4. Among them HCOOH, HCOONH4, HCOOK and HCOONa afford the best results (Fig. 5 ), out of which formic acid was choosen as it was readily available. Finally, to demonstrate the general applicability of this catalyst system, under the optimal reaction conditions established, various nitro compounds to the corresponding amines were investigated (Table 3 ). Specifically, it was observed that 2,4-dichloro-nitrobenzene (Table 3, entry 2b) was cleanly converted to the corresponding amine without any dehalogenation, which was often encountered with several previous hydrogenation procedures [37], It was found that functional groups like methoxy, ester, amide, sulfonyl and chloride present on the aromatic ring also remained unaffected during conversion to the amines (Table 3) by using this protocol. 3.6 General procedure for reduction A seal tube was charged with nitro compound (1 mmol), PS-[Fe(OH2)(2-TMBB-H)Cl3] complex (12 mol%), formic acid (3equivalence) in 6 mL ethyl acetate: water (1:1). The reaction mixture was heated to 70 °C for 6 hr. The reaction progress was monitored by TLC. After completion of the reaction, mixture was cooled to room temperature, filtered and basified, and the layer was separated, aqueous layer again extracted with (3 mL) ethyl acetate. The combined organic layer was washed with water (5 mL), dried over anhydrous sodium sulphate and the solvent was removed in vacuo. The crude product was purified using silica gel column chromatography. All the synthesised compounds were characterised through various spectroscopic techniques attached in the supplementary data. 3.7 Computational studies For proposing reaction mechanism for catalytic transfer hydrogenation using the polymer supported catalyst computational studies have been carried out. The electronic structure of each species in the paths 1 and 2 (Figs. 6 and 7 ) in the mechanism schemes were generated and optimized (Figs. 8 and 9 ) without any restraints using the Gaussian 09 software package with the CAM-B3LYP functional and the 6–31 + G* all-electron basis set [38]. The catalyst was modelled by representing the polymer as an ethyl group, finding it to be chemically stable with a HOMO-LUMO energy gap of 1.58 eV. The conversion of RNO2 to RNH2 involves nine intermediate species in path 1 (INT1 to INT9) and six intermediates in path 2 along the reaction pathways. Optimised geometries of the various intermediates involved for path 1 with important bond distances are depicted in Fig. 8 and for path 2 in Fig. 9. The mechanism begins with the substitution of chloride by the formate ion, which occurs in two steps via the Fe cation, requiring 8–10 kcal mol−1 energy gap. The formate ion can interact with the metal either through the oxygen atom of the formate group (INT1) via a covalent bond or through the H atom of the formate group via weak interactions (RINT1). As expected, the covalently bound INT1 is relatively more stable by 1 kcal mol−1 than RINT1. Subsequently, the NO2-containing compound coordinates to the metal center, replacing the water and forming INT2/RINT2. Steric hindrance leads to the removal of hydrogen atom and the release of CO2, resulting in the formation of INT3/RINT3. This stable intermediate can form with relatively less energy in RINT3, as the H atom points to the metal atom, required 3–5 kcal mol−1 of energy. It was noted that the H atom transfer from INT2 required 15–17 kcal mol−1. This hydrogen is then transferred to the NO2 group from the metal center, forming the intermediates NO2H. This step is repeated for all three chlorides, as shown in the energy profiles in Fig. 10 , resulting in the product via NHOH and NH2 species. Each chloride replacement requires more energy (0.2–0.5 kcal mol−1) due to the decreasing in electron withdrawing nature at the NO2 group by the addition of hydrogen atom [39]. The computational studies indicate the possible conversion of NO2 to NH2 with the help of Fe based catalyst, where each chloride ion can be replaced through a thermodynamically favorable pathway. Between the two pathways, the H-atom interaction path-2 is more feasible than the O-coordinated path-1. Overall, the conversion requires 10–13 kcal mol−1 energy (Fig. 10). The absence of a solvent environment in the computation might explain the highest energy barrier; however, a similar pathway is expected to be followed. Additionally, substituents are expected to affect the reaction barrier without altering the trend and pathway. 3.8 Heterogeneity and recycling ability of the catalyst To test heterogeneity of the reaction; 12 mol% catalyst was taken in 6 mL of solvent (water + ethyl acetate),1mmol of 4-nitrobenzoic acid and 3 equivalence of formic acid and the reaction was carried out at 70 °C. After 3 h, the catalyst was filtered and the reaction was allowed to continue for another 3 h. It was found that the conversion of nitro compound did not occur in absence of catalyst. After the reaction; the solution was tested for the presence of metal by ICP-OES. Absence of iron in the solution indicated that the leaching of the catalyst does not take place. After recycling the catalyst seven times, the iron content in the catalyst did not alter. This confirms that the catalyst is stable and truly heterogeneous in nature. At optimum reaction condition the conversion of p-nitro benzoic acid was carried out by the supported catalyst and it was separated from the reaction mixture, washed with methanol, dried and recycled seven times without much loss in activity (Fig. 11 ). The catalyst was efficient, stable and the iron content in it remained the same, after recycling seven times. Hence, the polymer supported catalyst showed excellent reusability and structural stability for amine synthesis. Under the optimised reaction conditions the conversion is carried out for unsupported complex; for it the yield was very low (50 %) and was not recyclable. Comparison of present work with literature is given in Table 4 . 4 Conclusion Ecofriendly method, environmentally benign route has been developed for selective nitro to amine conversion with inexpensive iron-based catalytic system. The simple method and easy workup procedure make the method most suitable for selective conversion of the nitro compounds. The optimum amount of polymer supported catalyst showed higher catalytic activity than the unsupported catalyst. The catalytic reactions were truly heterogeneous in nature. The computational studies determine the best suited pathway for the plausible mechanism for the reaction. The catalyst can be reused seven times without significant decrease in its activity. This work may provide novel insights into selective transfer hydrogenation. Overall, catalytical transfer hydrogen reaction shows high efficacy, safeness and sustainability. coredata.dc:description: This paper describes the synthesis, characterisation and catalytic transfer hydrogenation reaction of nitro compounds using HCOOH as hydrogen donor and functionalized chloromethylated polystyrene divinylbenzene supported iron complex as catalyst. It was characterized by various analytical techniques such as elemental analysis, ICP-OES, UV–VIS-DRS and FT-IR spectroscopic techniques, EDAX, and thermogravimetric analysis. This supported complex is an efficient catalyst for transfer hydrogenation reaction of aliphatic and aromatic nitro compounds which find application in the synthesis of fine chemicals, API’s and drugs. Interestingly this method has been proven to be tolerant to a broad range of functional groups with good to excellent yields and also established to be superior by exhibiting better catalytic activity and recyclability than the unsupported catalyst. The supported catalyst could be reused seven times without significant loss of catalytic activity. Density functional theory studies shreds light on the possible reaction pathways of transfer hydrogenation reaction catalyzed by Fe(III) system.
